title: Armed Forces Day

content: Armed Forces day used to be a big deal here, back when we had an Air Force base. The base was open to the public, with flight line aircraft displays, fly-overs, parachute drops, crash emergency drills etc. Kids and parents were allowed to crawl all over, and in, just about every aircraft in the inventory. And the public came. Usually, there were literally thousands of people there. Sadly, with the closing of the base back in the early 70's, Armed Forces day has become a non-event. A local VSO may do something, but nobody attends but a few of their members. Is this true everywhere else? Are there any current bases which are open to the public for Armed Forces day and does the public come?
reply: Armed Forces day used to be a big deal here, back when we had an Air Force base. The base was open to the public, with flight line aircraft displays, fly-overs, parachute drops, crash emergency drills etc. Kids and parents were allowed to crawl all over, and in, just about every aircraft in the inventory. And the public came. Usually, there were literally thousands of people there. Sadly, with the closing of the base back in the early 70's, Armed Forces day has become a non-event. A local VSO may do something, but nobody attends but a few of their members. Is this true everywhere else? Are there any current bases which are open to the public for Armed Forces day and does the public come?

title: Armed Forces Day

content: Snip from above article: "Today marks the 61st annual celebration of Armed Forces Day, begun in 1949 by Presidential Proclamation under President Truman. The celebration resulted from the consolidation of the five branches of military under the Department of Defense in that year. Its purpose is to set aside a day to honor, thank, and support the sacrifices, bravery, and patriotic service of our military forces. I can’t think of a job requiring greater sacrifice than to serve in our nation’s military, especially in time of war. I encourage all citizens to thank our soldiers personally. When you see a soldier in uniform, please take a moment to thank him or her. Support the American Legion and other military related organizations. Contact your elected representatives about legislation regarding our military. Attend welcome home events for our returning soldiers at the airport. Visit Walter Reed Hospital or write letters to our wounded soldiers. See the Link List on the right hand side of my article for information on how to Support Our Soldiers."
reply: Snip from above article: "Today marks the 61st annual celebration of Armed Forces Day, begun in 1949 by Presidential Proclamation under President Truman. The celebration resulted from the consolidation of the five branches of military under the Department of Defense in that year. Its purpose is to set aside a day to honor, thank, and support the sacrifices, bravery, and patriotic service of our military forces. I can’t think of a job requiring greater sacrifice than to serve in our nation’s military, especially in time of war. I encourage all citizens to thank our soldiers personally. When you see a soldier in uniform, please take a moment to thank him or her. Support the American Legion and other military related organizations. Contact your elected representatives about legislation regarding our military. Attend welcome home events for our returning soldiers at the airport. Visit Walter Reed Hospital or write letters to our wounded soldiers. See the Link List on the right hand side of my article for information on how to Support Our Soldiers."

content: Snip from above article: "Today marks the 61st annual celebration of Armed Forces Day, begun in 1949 by Presidential Proclamation under President Truman. The celebration resulted from the consolidation of the five branches of military under the Department of Defense in that year. Its purpose is to set aside a day to honor, thank, and support the sacrifices, bravery, and patriotic service of our military forces. I can’t think of a job requiring greater sacrifice than to serve in our nation’s military, especially in time of war. I encourage all citizens to thank our soldiers personally. When you see a soldier in uniform, please take a moment to thank him or her. Support the American Legion and other military related organizations. Contact your elected representatives about legislation regarding our military. Attend welcome home events for our returning soldiers at the airport. Visit Walter Reed Hospital or write letters to our wounded soldiers. See the Link List on the right hand side of my article for information on how to Support Our Soldiers."
